issue.title: CR+LF line endings in some of files
issue.body: I have noticed that `appveyor.yml` and `src/kem/sike/external/P751/AMD64/fp_x64_asm.S` have CR+LF (`\r\n`) line endings. While this is a very minute issue, some of tools employed in Debian packaging have minor problems with it (I should probably find a way to deal with them too). But if there is no difference, maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project? If this could not be done for `appveyor.yml` due to usage in Windows, maybe then line endings could be unified throughout all `*asm.S` files?

comment.body:
>  maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project?

`liboqs` has an [existing `astyle` check](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/run_astyle.sh) that [already enforces linux-style line endings](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/14d64d379def3a4745acb25a5a5c904bfbbf10f3/.astylerc#L16) . Until now this is only done on code controlled by `liboqs`, not external code, though (with the exception of `appveyor*`, which is an easy fix).

Before amending the existing `astyle` check, question to @merkys: Is the addition of the two files mentioned above to the `astyle` check sufficient or would you rather prefer (need?) `liboqs` enforces this on _all_ source code (or maybe only on "*.S" files)?

Question to @dstebila @christianpaquin : Can you remember the reason for excluding "external" code from `astyle` "enforcement"? After simply running `find appveyor* src tests -name '*.[chS]' | xargs astyle --options=.astylerc` everything keeps building and testing just fine -- after changing 2440 files to bring them "in line", though...

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
@anhu When trying to write user documentation for this image myself, I first wanted to use this and miserably failed: Build went OK,  `docker run -ti --net=host --privileged -v $HOME:/root:ro -e XAUTHORITY=/root/.Xauthority -e DISPLAY=$DISPLAY oqs-wireshark wireshark`  (sharing network interface and X-Windows DISPLAY) gets the window up, but then the console shows the following error messages (the last one appears for every mouse move and no text box is rendered OK):
```
$ docker run -it --net=host --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" oqs-wireshark wireshark
12:52:22.351     Main Warn QStandardPaths: XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not set, defaulting to '/tmp/runtime-root'
libGL error: MESA-LOADER: failed to retrieve device information
libGL error: MESA-LOADER: failed to open i915 (search paths /usr/lib/xorg/modules/dri)
libGL error: failed to load driver: i915
libGL error: failed to open drm device: No such file or directory
libGL error: failed to load driver: i965
libGL error: MESA-LOADER: failed to open swrast (search paths /usr/lib/xorg/modules/dri)
libGL error: failed to load driver: swrast
12:52:26.450     Main Warn QFont::setPointSizeF: Point size <= 0 (-0.750000), must be greater than 0
```

-> Do you have suggestions how to resolve this/how to get wireshark to render OK? Any prerequisites on the host that I may not have? 

Additional information: When creating a "plain ubuntu wireshark docker image" (installed into the docker image via `apt`), and running via the `docker run` command above, `wireshark` renders just fine....

issue.title: LF everywhere
issue.body:
Fixes #1129 

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

comment.body: I'm puzzled why Travis doesn't finish: @dstebila @bhess : As you arguably know Travis than me, could you please take a look? Thanks in advance.

comment.body:
> I'm puzzled why Travis doesn't finish: @dstebila @bhess : As you arguably know Travis than me, could you please take a look? Thanks in advance.

I assume it's just ephemeral quirks of Travis CI. I'm happy to merge this as is.

While this is a very minute issue, some of tools employed in Debian packaging have minor problems with it (I should probably find a way to deal with them too). But if there is no difference, maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project? If this could not be done for `appveyor.yml` due to usage in Windows, maybe then line endings could be unified throughout all `*asm.S` files?

comment.body:
> > maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project?
> 
> `liboqs` has an [existing `astyle` check](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/run_astyle.sh) that [already enforces linux-style line endings](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/14d64d379def3a4745acb25a5a5c904bfbbf10f3/.astylerc#L16) . Until now this is only done on code controlled by `liboqs`, not external code, though (with the exception of `appveyor*`, which is an easy fix).
> 
> Before amending the existing `astyle` check, question to @merkys: Is the addition of the two files mentioned above to the `astyle` check sufficient or would you rather prefer (need?) `liboqs` enforces this on _all_ source code (or maybe only on "*.S" files)?
> 
> Question to @dstebila @christianpaquin : Can you remember the reason for excluding "external" code from `astyle` "enforcement"? After simply running `find appveyor* src tests -name '*.[chS]' | xargs astyle --options=.astylerc` everything keeps building and testing just fine -- after changing 2440 files to bring them "in line", though...
> 
> Edit/Add: Running a less drastic `find appveyor.* src tests -name '*.[Sch]' | xargs sed -i 's/\r//'` indeed only highlights the file(s) above: PR #1133 . Will keep permitting possible future "visual" inspection of `copy_from_upstream` results.

Running astyle on all external code seemed to be too disruptive.  But I agree that running a check for line endings is a good idea.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body: I must admit that this PR has been somewhat of a lower priority and therefore I have been a bit sloppy. I didn't actually make it to execution of wireshark. I apologize for putting up a PR without fully trying the results.  I should have some time within the next few days to look into this.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
That'd be great: Thanks & looking forward to that!

The use case I'm thinking about (supporting/documenting) goes about like this: 
- Start wireshark (docker image)
- Enable filter for 149.81.106.123 (test.openquantumsafe.org interop server)
- Execute (via other docker image) (oqs-)`curl -k https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6001 --curves frodo640aes`
- Show/analyze TLS traffic in wireshark

--> Would you consider this realistic? My first mini-steps are pretty disappointing: It seems the Ubuntu-stock `wireshark` doesn't even recognize this as TLS traffic, let alone permitting analysis thereof :-( But then again, my wireshark "know-how" is dismal.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
> Would you consider this realistic?  

Yes!! Very realistic! In fact, it very much mirrors our own demo. 

1. start apache httpd built against wolfssl and liboqs
2. start wireshark (locally built, not docker image) and watch loopback
3. execute curl using falcon root cert and specify quantum safe group beside `--curves`. 
4. show analyze tls traffic in wireshark. 

If you stay tuned to wolfSSL's YouTube channel or get notifications of wolfSSL's webinars, sometime in the month of December, you'll probably be able to see such a demo. 

From what I remember stock, wireshark should recognize the traffic as TLS but not understand any of the groups nor signature schemes.  So, maybe something else has gone wrong? 

Another minor point is that you specify `frodo640aes` but please note that the patch does not allow for recognition of that particular codepoint.  Only SABER, KYBER, NTRU and their hybrids codepoints are recognized.  Of course, if you would like to add it, please feel free to do so.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.
SIKE not properly disabled on unsupported architectures
issue.body: With Debian now trying to [package liboqs](https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/liboqs), they build on a lot more platforms than we support, many of which [the build fails on](https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=liboqs).  I'm not suggesting we try to support those at this point in time.  However, one set of build failures (see e.g. [this build log](https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=liboqs&arch=mips64el&ver=0.7.0.27.gba5b61a7%2Bdfsg-1&stamp=1637141544&raw=0)) seems to be related to SIKE's config.h header file thinking it's on an unsupported architecture, but apparently CMake still tried to compile SIKE.  In other words, there seems to be a mismatch between architectures where CMake thinks it should try compiling SIKE and architectures that SIKE's config.h header file is willing to support.

comment.body: SIKE's config does explicitly reject unsupported platforms. I can add a compile guard in the CMakeLists building on non-supported platform. Do we have an environment to test this?
